label: Letter from Gertrude Sanford Legendre, August 26, 1942
description: Letter from Gertrude Legendre to her husband, Sidney Legendre, regarding scheduled phone calls with Sidney every other week, plans for the children, her job, and her social activities in Washington.

metadata.label: Description
metadata.value: Letter from Gertrude Legendre to her husband, Sidney Legendre, regarding scheduled phone calls with Sidney every other week, plans for the children, her job, and her social activities in Washington.

metadata.label: Transcript
metadata.value:
IB.
Aug 26.
Dear Sidney,
I have mailed you today via Navy Department letter NoI
I am writing you this one also to day via Pearl Harbor Navy Base
and am anxious to know'wh1ch one gets to Hawaii first. Be sure and let
me know. I told you in my letter about telephoning me . This can
be done easily. It costs II dollars for three minutes not much more
expensive than sending a cable. We should do this every couple of
weeks. The Operator notifies one two hours in advance the call is
comming through. If you would rather 1 call you tell me your home
telephone nomber so I can call at night. Its cheaper.
I count the days off thinking about your arrival in
Pearl Harbor. I do hope it was smooth and that you slept on deck.
I spoke to Miss Charlotte to-night on the telephone and
she does not like that School for Landine. She advises living at
Foxcroft and going to school at Middleburg. She wants Melle. to
teach French in Hiddleburg so that her wages will be less for me
which is a swell idea, I think it will work well. Miss Charlotte
wants Landine to be around Foxcroft and have piano lessons thereetc.
It would be perfect I think so thats the plan.
Bo and Landine are having a fine time in Watch Hill so
I shall leave them there as long as possible. Middleburg starts 
school the end of September.
[End Page 1]
2
My Job is going fine and I do like it. I walk or bicycle to work
every morning and play tennis some times in the afternoon. The w
weather has turned much cooler and is very pleasant.
I am going up to Ellen Frazer Saturday night to spend Sunday
which should be fun. The next one I shall go to Kathrines.
Every one asks about you and Morris and send you their, best.
I saw Nick Ludington the other day who said after the war he had
his life all planned. California in winter and Maine in Summer.
That was the top he thought, and I think thats pretty good dont you3 
I miss you so much its terrible. M  I hope this war does
not last too long. I cant bear it. I think about you so much andwant
so much to kiss you and tell you how much I love you.
Please give my love to Norris. i hope he is feeling alright.
Knoth writes he is going to South America for the Gov.and
that if we want the timber cut on Medway we should let him do it
in September before he goes. I shall write him we will do nothing
till after the war. Is that right?
Rose is,st1ll the cook and is wonderful. I dont know whatI
would do with out her. She is wonderful.
All my love my sweet ears. Goodnight with a hug and a fat kiss
my sweet heart.
Your-fat-
Gertie.
Can't wait for a letter from you.
[End Page 2]
